title: Local Roundup: Williams women's crew wins at Head of the Charles regatta
text:
Local Roundup: Williams women's crew wins at Head of the Charles regatta 
Berkshire Eagle Staff Posted: 10/19/2015 06:12:02 AM EDT Updated: 10/19/2015 07:15:24 AM EDT 
CAMBRIDGE — The last time a Williams College women's crew varsity eights won at the Head of the Charles Regatta in October, the Ephs went on to win an NCAA Division III championship in the spring. 
That may not happen this year, but Williams took the first step on Sunday, winning the women's collegiate varsity eights competition at the annual regatta held on the Charles River. It's Williams' fourth win on the Charles River and ended a three-year streak of no titles. 
Coach Kate Maloney's first varsity boat covered the course in 17 minutes, 25 seconds. The Ephs beat Mercyhurst (17:31) by six seconds. NESCAC rival Bates was third and Wellesley was fourth. 
"I don't draw any straight lines. I don't think it hurts their confidence and their belief in themselves," Maloney said last night. 
Williams last won on the Charles in 2011, and had also claimed wins in 2010 and 2008. 
"I wasn't expecting this," said Maloney, whose first year at Williams was 2011. "I wasn't surprised they were able to go out and generate some speed." 
Louisa Abel is the coxswain for the Ephs, and the boat was powered by Anne Tewksbury, Sophie Jannetty, Emily Strawn, Gemma Holt, Eileen Russell, Roberta Miller, Clara Beery and Katie Costantini. 
WILLIAMS MEN'S SOCCER 
At Babson Park, Williams erupted for four goals in the first half and routed Babson 7-2. Advertisement 
Mark Sisco-Tolomeo scored two goals for the Ephs (6-4-2). 
Christian Alcorn played the first half for Williams in goal, did not give up a score and made two saves. Bobby Schneiderman surrendered two second-half goals to Babson (7-6-2). 
Geoff Danilack and Mohammed Rashid each scored a goal and had two assists for the Ephs. High schools 
WAHCONAH GIRLS 2, HAMPSHIRE REGIONAL 0 
Saturday night in Dalton, host Wahconah controlled much of the game, but needed two second-half goals to pull off the victory. 
Jocelyn Hill broke the scoreless tie on a goal in the 56th minute and then with under four minutes to go, Amelia Dougherty set up Perin Genaway for the insurance tally. 
"Our two goals were the result of strong efforts on the part of the goal scorers and Amelia Dougherty," Wahconah coach Pat West wrote in an email. 
The Wahconah defense, led by Ashley Zink and Gianna Moncecchi helped limit the work goalkeeper Kayla Kowalczyk had to do. Kowalczyk made three saves as the Warriors had a 23-3 shot advantage. 
———
